ἆ The Asiarchs were originally the chief presidents of the religious rites in the Roman province Asia, whose duties consisted in giving every year games and theatrical amuse- ments in honour of the Roman emperor and the gods. The religious character of the office disappeared with the establishment of Christianity. The word occurs in Acts xix. 31 and in the letter of the Church of Smyrna about the martyrdom of Polycarp. Here the presence of the word is surprising‚ unless it be either a synonym for ‘⁶ pro-consul'' or a proper name. There is an excellent account of the pagan Asiarchate in Lightfoot, Apostolic Fathers, pt. ii. vol. iii. pp. 404415.
